title: 113_s1484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013". Definitions are provided in the Act. The term "Authority" in the Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 refers to the Sabine River Authority of Texas. The term "Federal land" includes National Forest System land within the Sabine National Forest and the Toledo Bend Project boundary in Texas, as well as additional Federal land occupied by Forest Service campgrounds adjacent to the Toledo Bend Project. The Secretary and the Authority mutually agree on the land adjacent to the Toledo Bend Project, depicted on the map. Non-Federal land refers to private land near Sabine National Forest owned or to be acquired by the Authority. The Secretary is the Secretary of Agriculture, and the Toledo Bend Project is a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission project numbered 2305. The Toledo Bend Project is identified as the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission project numbered 2305. The wilderness area is defined as the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in the Sabine National Forest. Wilderness candidate land refers to the surface estate of land adjacent to the wilderness area, to be agreed upon by the Authority and the Secretary. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE, SABINE NATIONAL FOREST. In exchange for non-Federal land, wilderness candidate land, and any cash payment, the Secretary will convey all US rights to the Federal land. The conveyance is subject to existing rights, and an appraisal must be completed within 180 days according to specific standards. The appraisal for the Federal land must adhere to specific standards including the Uniform Appraisal Standards for Federal Land Acquisitions and the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice. The Secretary must consider any restrictions on the land's use imposed by a restrictive covenant. Additionally, a survey must be conducted to determine the exact acreage and legal description of the Federal land, non-Federal land, and wilderness candidate land. The exact acreage and legal description of the Federal land, non-Federal land, and wilderness candidate land for conveyance shall be determined by surveys or other agreed means. Costs for the land exchange will be shared equally between the Authority and the Secretary. The exchange will be conducted on an equal value basis, and cash equalization may be used to equalize land values. The Secretary may receive cash equalization payments exceeding the statutory limit, which will be deposited into a specific fund and used for land acquisition for the National Forest System. Title to non-Federal land conveyed must be acceptable to the Secretary. Title to non-Federal land conveyed to the Secretary must be acceptable and conform to title approval standards. The deed of conveyance must reserve any subsurface mineral estate owned by the United States. A restrictive covenant must be included in the deed of conveyance. The Secretary must include a covenant in the deed of conveyance for Federal land, ensuring it is used in a manner consistent with adjacent National Forest System land, remain unsubdivided, and not used for commercial, residential, or industrial development. The covenant does not create any property interest of the United States. The Authority can continue operating Forest Service campgrounds conveyed under subsection (a) with authorization from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The land exchange authorized by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission must be completed within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Boundary adjustment for Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest. Boundary Adjustment: After completing the land exchange, the Secretary will modify the boundaries of the wilderness area. This includes excluding wilderness area land within the Toledo Bend Project and adding acquired wilderness candidate land to the wilderness area. The excluded land will no longer be part of the wilderness designation, while the included land will be designated as wilderness. After the land exchange, the Secretary will adjust the boundaries of the wilderness area and submit a map and legal description to the relevant committees for approval. The map and description will be available for public inspection. The map and legal description for the adjusted boundaries of the wilderness area will be available for public inspection in the appropriate Forest Service offices.
